text: Patient: Okay. Question. Sixteen to seventeen, and I don’t know the time frame that it went from sixteen to seventeen, but in (cell phone rings) Doctor: Yeah, don’t read much into it. You know, we’re just checking it more often. Patient: Well, I understand that, but what does that mean to the aggressiveness of the cancer? Does it - Doctor: Okay. Yeah, I mean my sense is that people who, let’s - I don’t have prostate cancer that I know of right now - but, if my PSA was going up and I don’t have the diagnosis, it sort of tells me if it’s going up that fast that I’m more likely when I put a needle in it to find bad cancer. So, we already know you’ve got bad cancer. Patient: Yeah. So, this is, doesn’t tell you. Doctor: Doesn’t tell you. Patient: Then, why do I keep getting stuck? Doctor: Uh, because - Doctor: You know, we’re about ready to start, you know, a trial or a drug, uh, you know, so, Patient: So, you need that base, a current baseline? Doctor: Yeah, we wanna know where you are as we get started. Patient: And that’s understandable. Doctor: It’s your turn. I want you to do that for me.

text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay that’s where you switched to? text: Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: Oh, and, let me not forget that you’re also a candidate for a study called, Iron Man. Family Member: Hum. Doctor: Which is an international study where you would there donate once a year a tube of blood, or is it two? Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And you fill out questionnaires to share with people about your journey. You know? How is this helping? Not helping? What don’t you like? Family Member: Oh. Doctor: I fill stuff out, too. And then we get all this data together- Family Member: Right. Doctor: - so that people in Brazil and Australia, and, you know, Ireland, all go and answer the same set of questionnaires. So it’s really fascinating because there’s a lot of people like you just all around the world. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Anyway, so, we want you to pony up to that, too. So if that’s not enough to overwhelm you, um, let me know. I can always do more. Patient: Okay. I just need somebody to send me like ah-

text: Patient: You know I was reading an article a while back that I like about it’s going to become common for folks to live into their hundreds. Doctor: Perhaps. Patient: The article mentioned about a miracle drug performing. Metforim. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: So I had stashed away and I should be doing this. But I started taking five hundred milligrams Metformin I meant to talk to you the last time I was here. Doctor: Now in the past we because the glucosol Patient: Yes, yes. But we found that to be one of the cholesterol medications I was taking at the time. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And plus that in addition to I was getting a little cramp in my side. And so we stopped. Doctor: Well with age, so-called metabolic syndrome increases in many people. And so what that means is you know your sugar levels become higher and um your metabolism changes in such a way as a result of that. And this may also cause other downstream effects on the down the line. For example, it might slightly increase the risk of having a cardio-vascular disease or a heart attack, for example, or cerebral-vascular disease like a stroke. If the blood glucose level is not controlled over time. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So all of the things that Metformin does is it changes your metabolism in such a way that the blood glucose level is lower and therefore it puts you at decreased risk of dying with those things that I mentioned. Patient: I’m sorry, it also mentioned that Metformin is a cancer fighter.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Even the PET scan. You know, sensitive but not that sensitive. Patient: Right. Doctor: If it’s just a small amount of cells, but it is enough of a sign for me. text: Patient: Radiation treatment was. Doctor: Yeah. Exactly. Patient: So it wasn’t doing anything up here or the middle of the spine. Doctor: No. No. Right. And that would be true for proton. Protons are you know there’s a spot I want and- Patient: Site specific. Doctor: Very. So the question is do you color right up to the line you know with a two millimeter ballpoint pen or do you have a five millimeter ballpoint pen. So you’re trying to cut it out and draw an outline. You know? Will you get more precise? Yeah you might get more precise but is there any meaning to that for the patient. And that’s what we don’t know. So new stuff. text: Patient: I see. Doctor: That’s the criteria. Patient: I see. Doctor: So this PSMA scan picks up those normal things that are too small. Doctor: So you’ve got to be prepared for that kind of news that there’s more there. Patient: Well I mean it’s- Doctor: It’s not always like that but it’s possible. Patient: No. No. No. It’s better to know what you’re dealing with than not. What about the treatment side of it in Europe? I mean what do they do once, let’s say you’re a candidate. Doctor: It’s a, uh, it’s a little very tiny little piece of just a little chemical.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
